factoid: The army advanced two days' march on the eighteenth and nineteenth of November.
The enemy's outposts retreated after a brief interchange of shots on the eighteenth and nineteenth of November.
A great, excitedly bustling activity began in the highest army circles from midday on the nineteenth of November.
The activity lasted until the morning of the twentieth of November.
The memorable battle of Austerlitz was fought on the morning of the twentieth of November.
Until midday on the nineteenth of November, the activity was confined to the Emperor’s headquarters.
On the afternoon of the nineteenth of November, the activity reached Kutúzov’s headquarters and the staffs of the commanders of columns.
By evening on the nineteenth of November, adjutants had spread the activity to all ends and parts of the army.
From the night of the nineteenth to the twentieth of November, all eighty thousand allied troops rose from their bivouacs to the hum of voices.
The army swayed and started in one enormous mass six miles long.
The concentrated activity began at the Emperor’s headquarters in the morning.
The activity started the whole movement that followed.
The activity was like the first movement of the main wheel of a large tower clock.
One wheel slowly moved, another was set in motion, and a third wheel began to revolve faster.
Levers and cogwheels worked as a result of the activity.
Chimes played as a result of the activity.
Figures popped out as a result of the activity.
The hands advanced with regular motion as a result of the activity.
An impulse once given leads to the final result in the mechanism of a clock.
Parts of the mechanism remain quiescent until the impulse reaches them.
Wheels creak on their axles as the cogs engage one another.
Revolving pulleys whir with the rapidity of their movement.
A neighboring wheel is quiet and motionless until the lever catches it.
When a lever catches a wheel, the wheel begins to creak and joins in the common motion.
The result of the complicated motion of innumerable wheels and pulleys is a slow and regular movement of the hands that show the time.
The result of all the complicated human activities of 160,000 Russians and French was only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz.
The battle of Austerlitz is also called the battle of the three Emperors.
Prince Andrew was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the commander in chief.
At six in the evening on the nineteenth of November, Kutúzov went to the Emperor’s headquarters.
Kutúzov stayed a short time with the Tsar.
Kutúzov then went to see the grand marshal of the court, Count Tolstóy.
Bolkónski went to get some details of the coming action from Dolgorúkov.
Bolkónski felt that Kutúzov was upset and dissatisfied about something.
Bolkónski felt that at headquarters they were dissatisfied with Kutúzov.
Bolkónski felt that at the Emperor’s headquarters everyone adopted a tone toward Kutúzov of men who know something others do not know.
Bolkónski wished to speak to Dolgorúkov.
Dolgorúkov was sitting at tea with Bilíbin.
Dolgorúkov said that the fete is for tomorrow.
Dolgorúkov asked Prince Andrew how he was.
Dolgorúkov said that Prince Andrew would like to be heard.
Dolgorúkov said that they heard him at the council of war and would hear him when he talks sense.
Dolgorúkov said that Bonaparte fears nothing so much as a general battle is impossible.
Prince Andrew asked about Bonaparte.
Dolgorúkov answered that Bonaparte fears nothing so much as a general engagement.
Dolgorúkov repeated that Bonaparte is afraid of a general battle.
Dolgorúkov said that Bonaparte’s hour has come.
